article.description: Richard Roby scored 22 points, Marcus Hall added 17 and Colorado withstood a big second-half run by Texas (No. 22 ESPN/USA Today, No. 23 AP) to beat the short-handed Longhorns
article.headline: Texas down to seven scholarship players
article.story: BOULDER, Colo. (AP) -- Watching his team miss shot after shot and Texas score on just about every trip at the other end, Colorado coach Ricardo Patton couldn't hide from his thoughts. "I was hoping the clock would run out, that was my first wish," he said. That didn't happen, but Patton got his second wish: the Buffaloes held on. Richard Roby scored 22 points, Marcus Hall added 17 and Colorado withstood a big second-half run by Texas (No. 22 ESPN/USA Today, No. 23 AP) to beat the short-handed Longhorns 88-79 on Tuesday night. Colorado (12-9, 4-6 Big 12) led by as many as 21 points, got lackadaisical to let Texas back in it, then pulled away to beat the Longhorns for just the second time in nine games. The Buffaloes did it with five players in double figures, pressure defense on Texas' top scorer and an efficient offense, finishing with five turnovers -- its lowest total since 1982. "I think this team has shown the ability that it can handle failure when we have bounced back," Patton said. "But I was concerned with us being able to handle success. I did not want us to forget how to remain focused." Texas (15-7, 4-5) got a huge game from Brad Buckman, who finished with 27 points and 21 rebounds -- most by a Texas player since LaSalle Thompson had 21 in 1982. Jason Klotz was solid as well, adding 16 points and some key shots during Texas' second-half run. It just wasn't enough. The Longhorns didn't have anything left after trimming away most of Colorado's big lead and couldn't overcome an off-night from freshman Daniel Gibson, who shot 4-of-12 and had eight turnovers after leading Texas in scoring the previous six games. One of the nation's top teams to start the season, Texas has lost four of five and will likely drop out of the polls after being ranked as high as No. 10 just a month ago. "I can sit here and rave about the fact that we (came back) from whatever it was we were down, but that's not what it's about," Texas coach Rick Barnes said. "We shouldn't have gotten down like that. We didn't have to get down like that if we had done a better job on the offensive end." Down to seven scholarship players -- three freshmen -- because of injuries and grades, the Longhorns were miserable in the first half and didn't get much better to start the second, falling behind 58-36 with 14 minutes left. Texas tightened up at both ends to get back in it. Working the ball inside to Buckman and Klotz, the Longhorns freed up their shooters on the perimeter, hitting four 3-pointers during a 21-3 run that cut Colorado's lead to 61-57 with 7½ minutes left. Texas was just as good at the other end, forcing Colorado into tough shots and bad passes. The Buffaloes missed 11 of 12 shots during Texas' run and didn't seem like they'd be able to hold on. "I felt things were slipping away," Roby said. But Colorado built its lead back up as quickly as it lost it. Hall hit a 3-pointer, Andy Osborn dropped in a baseline jumper and Hall added two free throws to put the Buffaloes up 70-59 with 4:45 left. Texas trimmed the lead to 83-77 on Kenny Taylor's consecutive 3-pointers in the final minute, but Colorado went 5-of-6 from the free throw line to seal it. The Longhorns were lucky to have even had a chance with the way they started the game. Forcing passes in traffic and misfiring from all angles -- at least three shots hit the side of the backboard in the first half alone -- Texas missed 13 of 16 shots midway through the first half to fall behind by 15. The Longhorns shot just 30 percent in the half and spent a good portion of halftime bickering and yelling at each other. "We were horrible on offense to start the game and couldn't find any rhythm at all," Barnes said. Texas' defense was only marginally better. The bigger Longhorns were effective at keeping the Buffaloes from scoring inside, but didn't rotate quick enough get out on their shooters. Swinging the ball around the wings for numerous open looks against Texas' zone, Colorado hit four 3-pointers during an 18-5 run that put them up 29-16 with just over 4 minutes left. The Buffaloes were just 7-of-21 from long range, but it was plenty good enough considering the Longhorns were just 1-for-9. Texas switched to a man-to-man defense late in the half, but it didn't slow Colorado. The Buffaloes started penetrating the lane for runners and floaters, with Jason Obazuaye and Hall each hitting two to put Colorado up 40-25 at halftime.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
